In 1864, Grant became the general-in-chief of the Union army, a position he held throughout the war, in which he led the Union to victory with his strategic genius and indomitable spirit.

After the war, Grant embarked on a diplomatic mission to China but soon returned to the United States, where he ran unsuccessfully for a seat in the U.S. Senate. In 1868, he was elected as the 18th President of the United States, defeating Democratic candidate Horatio Seymour. Grant's presidency focused on enforcing the Reconstruction Amendments and the passage of the 15th Amendment, which aimed to protect the voting rights of African-American men.

Despite his efforts, Grant faced challenges during his administration, including the Panic of 1873 and political scandals such as the Whiskey Ring, in which his administration was implicated. Nonetheless, he remains known for his contributions to ending the Civil War and preserving the Union.
